dcterms:creator: Luzi Sennhauser
Robert Berwick
dcterms:description: The Dyck language is a canonical example of a context-free language, consisting of all balanced strings of parentheses and square brackets, used to evaluate LSTMs' ability to learn hierarchical dependencies.
dcterms:title: Dyck Language

dcterms:creator: Jeffrey L. Elman
dcterms:description: Strictly piecewise (SP) languages are regular languages defined by the presence or absence of certain subsequences, used to test LSTMs' ability to learn long-distance dependencies.
dcterms:title: Strictly Piecewise (SP) Languages

dcterms:creator: Patrick C. Fischer
dcterms:description: Counter languages are recognized by automata equipped with counters, used to evaluate LSTMs' ability to capture counting dependencies.
dcterms:title: Counter Languages
